author: AceMcNasty
body:
Depends on the complexity of the strategy and things like what’s the likelihood of hitting both TP and SL intrabar; or are you going to enter on say 1H and then go down to 1M so you’ll know which is hit first?

Your results would be very accurate if it was “go long 100 pip tp and sl, using 1M”, but it would very inaccurate if it was “go long with 0.2x Atr tp and a 22pip sl using a weekly chart”.

Generally speaking my mean reversion strategies are extremely accurate when back tested, but the trend strategies can be wildly different. The latter having more calculations and variables.

Using a non-standard chart can also skew your results, ex using a 3 line break chart (this is a chart type, not ma cross or whatever people are going to reply with as minds get blown anytime I mention line break) is only accurate if you enter/exit when a new bar is drawn, you won’t be using typical tp and sl values. Plus you have to set it to 1 bar then you can trade a 3 bar with overlay as testing 3 bar directly is WIlDLY inaccurate.

author: mr_holgrave
body:
Keep struggling, my man. I think every successful trader has gone through the same journey at some point. It's not easy and the school fees are expensive. 

My strategy essentially involves looking at higher time frames for directional bias and price levels that form structures / significant levels. Then, observe how the lower time frames react to those levels / ranges of price. 

I would also recommend getting a solid risk management strategy in place. I never risk more than 1% on a single position and have a maximum number of positions I'm willing to take in a single day.

Your job as a trader is to minimize as many risk factors as possible before entering a position and by finding as much confluence across the chart time frames as you can.

Stop looking for a strategy you can copy, go learn different concepts, and apply them until something sticks. Lastly, wanting a specific RR and win rate is going to keep you stuck where you are. Focus on concepts and learning how the market moves.


Good luck!

author: AceMcNasty
body:
I don't even know why y'all buy his BS in the first place (well, I do know, he's one hell of a good marketer). But seriously, liquidity? With FX, especially majors, there isn't a liquidity gap. He's talking about stuff that happens with things like low volume options trading, not FX. FX the market makers ensure liquidity which is why your orders basically always get filled at the point you want.

Untaken liquidity is something like me wanting, I don't know, PEGY calls for June 28. On June 27 I want to sell my option for $20 but there's only buyers at $1 and below. Now I can either hold (and probably lose my premium) or I can take the $1 which would be a liquidity gap since no one was willing to do a deal at the prices between. That sort of stuff doesn't happen with retail FX. You'll be filled basically anytime, any price. There is no untaken liquidity.

>is my understanding of the silver bullet strategy correct?

You might understand the strategy correct, but the guy telling it to you has one goal. Make money for himself. Wanna know where his money comes from? YouTube ads. So, he got to keep you watching. He is actually NOT incentivized to teach you; he benefits far more if you don't learn a thing and keep watching his videos. That's why he makes everything super complicated, and then you can never blame him as he always has a way out. Oh, you missed the FVG? Ah that's because of untaken liquidity and there wasn't a bump, rocket, bump, or whatever the f\* he calls it.

>if not, what liquidity should we hunt for (previous hour, session, or day )?

None, because you're literally hunting for Big Foot at this point.

You can get mentored by the best trader in the world or take a million different courses but if YOU don't put in the work required to become profitable you will never become profitable. author: sanarilian
body:
I normally don't bother to respond. Your post sounds sincere and resonates with my beliefs. I can't tell you exactly my strategy, but I will share my journey and how I arrived at my mechanical strategy. 
First of all, I just have to vent that a lot of the comments here criticize you for not trying hard enough on this and that, psychology is wrong, blah, blah. They don't know you, how dare they blame you for anything.
I started with manual trading and ended up as an algorithmic trader. I automated and tested literally 120+ strategies including news utilizing strategies over 18 years of data. My conclusion is that the forex market is very noisy. There are a lot of randomness in the price movements, at all practical time scales, which don't really correlate to anything else. All the pattern based entry and exit strategies don't really work. They may be profitable for a period of time out of luck. It has nothing to do with psychology because my test programs don't have emotions. None of the price actions or indicators has predictive power in short term. I am quoting out of my experience, not from any book. This is the reason that many algo traders avoid forex.
I am not saying there are no profitable manual traders. I can't prove it either way. Who am I to condemn everyone. I am just saying I gave up on manual, technical or fundamental trading, and highly skeptical if anyone can.
Algo trading is the way for me. The approach has to be statistical meaning you can't say which trade will win, but you can say what percentage of your trade will win. Because I found the market statistics don't change too much in a year to year basis. So, learn programming, statistics, probability and make an algo trading machine for yourself.

author: Blaiddyn
body:
You're troubleshooting the wrong issue. You should be troubleshooting your risk management and maybe the effectiveness of the execution of your strategy. 

You could have a strategy that says if I flip a coin and get heads I'll go long and if I get tails I'll go short. If you implemented that strategy you'd be right 50% of the time over a long period of time. Where risk management comes in is calculating your position size correctly and having a favorable risk to reward ratio. If you have a 50% win rate that is correlated to a 2:1 risk reward ratio, for example, you'd be a profitable trader assuming you are calculating your position size correctly and you are effective at executing your strategy.

You can't out trade bad risk management.

author: SomethingAgainstD0gs
body:
Becoming break even, or hell, even losing at a slow rate is a massive win and the first step to profitablity. Obviously, don't jump strategies too often but you still have to use both back and forward testing to see the tiny tweaks you need to change. Think of it like using the scientific method and having very micro, marginal changes over time.

And example for me was: I had gotten out of a massive losing streak with the strategy I currently use (which losing streaks are normal and don't mean anything is wrong). However, my profits were still coming in very very slowly. I had been using a 1:1 rr. My win rate was 50%. But i saw that during my wins, the charts would often go pass my tp. Hypothesis: raising my rr from 1:1 to 1:1.5 would decrease my win rate but make my profits bigger. I forward tested it on a fake account for a while and my win rate dropped to around 35-40ish%. Then over time, I noticed it would still blow pass my tp, wash, rinse, and repeat.

I did that with other things about my strategy as well but long story short, be a scientist.
